awd_titl_txt: Sunlight Driven Chemistry in Aqueous Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation, Professor Veronica Vaida at the University of Colorado-Boulder studies the sunlight-initiated chemistry of organic molecules. The research program addresses the following questions: What role does sunlight-initiated chemistry in aqueous environments play in altering organic molecules in the atmosphere? How do photochemical reactions affect the molecules in the sea surface and atmospheric aerosol particles? What are the non-biological mechanisms for particle formation, which use sunlight as the energy source and aqueous interfaces as reaction media? To what extent can laboratory data be used to model realistic environmental chemistry? By answering these questions, students and postdoctoral fellows gain broad expertise and skills in atmospheric chemistry.  The students are guided by an international and interdisciplinary team of colleagues with complementary knowledge base and skill sets. The scientific exchange between investigators and interdisciplinary international collaborators significantly broadens the educational experience of all those involved in this project.

This work derives molecular-level mechanisms and quantitative models for atmospheric photochemistry that occur in different phases, including gaseous and aqueous phases and at the surface of water. These photochemical reactions play an important role in the formation and chemical evolution of atmospheric aerosols with potentially important consequences to human health and climate change. This investigation examines the basic scientific aspects of sunlight-initiated, water-mediated, chemical reactivity of organic molecules. Using a combination of laboratory and theoretical studies, the outcome of the research is an improved understanding of the mechanisms, dynamics, and rates of photochemical reactions occurring in clusters and on aerosol surfaces that are of importance in the atmosphere.

por.por_cntn:
The grant “Sunlight Driven Chemistry in Aqueous Environments,” enabled the study of the multiphase photoreactivity of atmospheric molecules in gas and aqueous phases and at water surface.  The intellectual merit is in finding specific chemistry in different environments with distinct chemical processes at water surfaces.

A combined laboratory and environmental chamber studies was used to understand atmospheric chemical processes in heterogeneous environments. The photon and water-mediated chemistry of organic targets was studied at CU Boulder in the Vaida laboratories and in an environmental simulation chamber in collaboration with Prof. Jean-Francois Doussin (CESAM, LISA, Universite Paris Est, France).  The environmental chamber study followed the photoreactivity of organic compounds in gas phase, in microdroplets and on the surface of aqueous droplets. In Boulder, the photochemistry of monolayers of organic compounds deposited on a liquid water surface was investigated to find that the water surface is a special reaction environment where chemical processes not possible in bulk aqueous solution, take place readily. To study the water-surface, technical developments were necessary including the development of surface reflection spectroscopy in the IR as well as the UV as well as specialized photochemical experiments able to illuminate the surface of water. With this instrumentation the morphology of organic molecules at the water surface was investigated leading to observation of chemical reactions such as amide bond formation (see figure 1), esterification  and oligomerization (see figure 2).

Atmospheric models use bulk aqueous phase reactions to model the chemistry of atmospheric aerosols. In contrast, results from this study suggest that the unique chemistry at the aerosol surface is the dominant path for the heterogeneous processing of organic compounds in the natural environment.

Water surfaces also provide special reaction environments in biology. Using the technology developed, organic surfactant films at the surface of water which provided models for biological membranes were investigated and provided insight into diseases such as phenylketonuria.

The fundamental study of chemistry in aqueous environments had a broad impact in environmental and biological chemistry. In addition, this interdisciplinary project provided a unique opportunity for education and outreach. The work involved interdisciplinary collaborations between theory and experiment and between the fields of chemistry and environmental science, providing ideal and far-reaching opportunities for education. The teaching of chemistry through environmental problems was implemented in research, in the classroom, and in outreach settings. Thus, furthering the use of alternative teaching models in undergraduate courses that incorporated examples from environmental chemistry. In addition, the work provided the opportunity to bring interdisciplinary ideas from chemistry and environmental science to non-scientific audiences (e.g., lectures for the Center for the History and Philosophy of Science). The project included a diverse team of undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and visitors and it involved international collaborations and student exchanges. New projects were initiated working with graduate and undergraduate students from France and Denmark. These collaborations yielded joint publications and student exchanges. All scientists working on these projects acquired a strong background in spectroscopy and photochemistry, performed works on experimental and computational aspects of the project, and worked with diverse, international  groups to better appreciate the global scientific enterprise.     Lectures for students K-12 were developed and presented by Veronica Vaida to convey to students the diversity of science and scientists.
